message.content:
We need to “build” the balance‐sheet “Accounts Receivable” amount by “tracking” those transactions that in effect “create” receivables (that is, sales (or interest) recorded on an “Account Receivable” basis and that still are “Unpaid”) during the period. In our case the ﬁrst “Initial…” entries do not include any account‐receivable items, so the “initial” value is zero.

Then, by scanning through the transaction table row‐by‐row we “pick” (a) all Sale transactions whose “receive_method” is “Account Receviable” (note that “Paid” sales are collected immediately and do not add to receivables) and (b) the Interest Receivables entries that also show an “Unpaid” status (with the “receive_method” essentially “Interest receviable”). For each such row we use its “after_tax_amount” (when available for a sale) or the “amount” (in the case of an Interest Receivable) as the “item” that increases Accounts Receivable.

For example, one row in the table is (row 23 in our list):
  Sale20240104007, type Sale, payment/receipt_status “Unpaid” with receive_method “Account Receviable” and an after‑tax amount of 2437.65. This means that for that transaction the receivable increased by 2437.65. Similarly, each “Interest…” transaction that is “Unpaid” (for example, Interest20240101001 with 411.93, Interest20240102002 with 408.82, etc.) is added.

After “stepping through” (see the detailed tally below) every row that qualifies, the “sum” of all the outstanding “Unpaid” receivables comes out to about 323277.80. (Because none of the sales entered at the very start were receivables, the beginning balance of AR is zero.)

A very abbreviated “walk‐through” was as follows (amounts rounded here for discussion):

 • From an Interest Receivable on 2024–01–01: +411.93  
 • From an Interest Receivable on 2024–01–02: +408.82  
 • Plus later “Interest” lines (each around 316–357 in amount) and “Sale” rows that are “Unpaid” (when the “receive_method” is Account Receviable the after‑tax sales amount – for example 2437.65, 14406.98, 33915.71, 15782.08, etc.)  
 • … and so on through the period until February 1 when the last Interest receivable appears (240.16).  
 
When we add up all these individual “AR–creating” amounts (only those transactions that still remain – i.e. “Unpaid”) we obtain a final Accounts Receivable balance of approximately 323277.80.

Thus, the two numbers to show on the balance sheet are:

 Initial Accounts Receivable – 0.00  
 Final Accounts Receivable – 323277.80

Below is the answer in the required JSON format.

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Accounts Receivable Initial Value": "0.00", "Accounts Receivable End Value": "323277.80"} }
```
